thread.title: Ohio minimum wage amendment clears initial hurdle, would raise minimum wage to $12 an hour
thread.title_full: Ohio minimum wage amendment clears initial hurdle, would raise minimum wage to $12 an hour | cleveland.com

author: Jackie Borchardt, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Ohio minimum wage amendment clears initial hurdle, would raise minimum wage to $12 an hour
text:
COLUMBUS, Ohio -- Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine on Friday certified petition language for a proposed constitutional amendment that would increase the minimum wage to $12 an hour by 2021.
DeWine does not judge the merit of proposed amendments -- only whether the summary that will appear on petitions accurately describes the proposed ballot issue.
The measure now goes to the Ohio Ballot Board, which will decide whether the proposed amendment is one or multiple issues, before supporters can begin collecting the 305,591 signatures necessary to put the issue before voters in 2016.
The Ohio Fair Wage Amendment would increase the minimum wage to $10 an hour on Jan. 1, 2017 and 50 cents per hour each year after until it reaches $12 an hour in 2021. After 2021, the minimum wage would be adjusted for inflation under current Ohio law.
The amendment would require employers to pay tipped employees $6 per hour in 2017 and increase wages by $1 per hour each year until it equals the full minimum wage.
Ohio voters approved annual increases tied to inflation through a 2006 amendment to the state Constitution . In 2015, the state minimum wage increased 15 cents to $8.10 an hour and the minimum wage for tipped workers increased 7 cents to $4.05 an hour.
Stand Up for Ohio, a coalition of community, labor, civil rights, and environmental groups, is backing the amendment. The group was founded by Communications Workers of America members in 2011 and helped organize opposition to Senate Bill 5 that year.
Ohio Senate Democrats proposed raising the minimum wage to $10.10 in 2016 , but the bill likely won't pass the Republican-controlled Statehouse.
